qas.question: About how many tonnes of uranium is theorized to be present in the sea?
The presence of what substance in sea water has resulted in low yields when attempting to extract uranium?
What did ORNL call their material that performs surface retention on solid molecules?
About how many tonnes of uranium is theorized to be absent in the sea?
The presence of what substance in fresh water has resulted in low yields when attempting to extract uranium?
What did ORNL call their material that performs surface retention on liquid molecules?

context: An additional <a0_0><b5_0>4.6 billion<b5_0/><a0_0/> tonnes of uranium are estimated to be in sea water (Japanese scientists in the 1980s showed that extraction of uranium from sea water using ion exchangers was technically feasible). There have been experiments to extract uranium from sea water, but the yield has been low due to the <a1_0><b6_0>carbonate<b6_0/><a1_0/> present in the water. In <a4_0><b9_0>2012<b9_0/><a4_0/>, ORNL researchers announced the successful development of a new absorbent material dubbed <a2_0><b7_0>HiCap<b7_0/><a2_0/> which performs surface retention of solid or gas molecules, atoms or ions and also effectively removes toxic metals from water, according to results verified by researchers at <a3_0><b8_0>Pacific Northwest National Laboratory<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
